A gunman opened fire at a video game tournament killing multiple people and then fatally shooting himself in a rampage that wounded several othersOne of the pirates had the cheek to say to him, as if it was all his fault, “You have made a mistake.”&nbspIt is a phrase that haunts him even to this day. For a long while in captivity, he felt the pirates were right about that: “I was a tall, white man hoping to make friends with pirates. Crazy.”&nbspBeing a writer meant that he was worth something. “I have seen you on the internet,” said one of his captors. “You are famous.”&nbspHe denied it. Then they fished out a picture of him that had appeared in the New York Times. I had even contributed in a small way to adding to the price on his head by writing an enthusiastic review of his surfing book in that newspaper. The asking price was $20m. If only I’d slated his book it might have brought the price down by a few million. His friends soon learned he had been kidnapped but we were warned not to write anything. Every time his name was mentioned on the BBC his price went up again.He was regularly beaten, and threatened with torture, or being handed over to al-Shabaab, but one of the worst things about being held in captivity is not having anything to read. One of the highlights of his first few months was piecing together fragments of The Gulf News&nbspwhich had been wrapping up samosas. Taken to a ship a mile offshore, the Naham 3 – a highjacked fishing vessel – he was given a Bible by one of his fellow hostages. A lapsed Catholic, he read it twice from cover to cover, having to squint all the while, but finding consolation in “the gritty survival ethic” of the Old Testament. He decided he was not so keen on crucifixion as such.There were a lot of guards on the ship, and a fair few sharks in the water too. And without glasses he could barely make out where he was going. But in the end he leapt off the ship in a bid for freedom. He didn’t make it and spent the next three&nbspweeks chained up in solitary confinement. I read a story online about how he had been shot while trying to escape. This turned out to be a myth put about by the pirates themselves, with a notion of speeding up delivery of the ransom.Around this time Moore devoutly wished he had become an astronaut – or anything – rather than a writer. As a kid, his bedroom had been decorated with astronaut wallpaper, peppered with rockets and moons and stars. Now marooned on board a very terrestrial ship, he was tormented by dreams and rumours of a rescue that never came. But there was still one option available to him. He could try and shoot his way out. It would be the heroic thing to do. But it would also be stupid. The guards had a habit of leaving their Kalashnikovs lying about. There was zero chance of getting away but he could go out in a blaze of glory and bullets, and maybe take a pirate or two down with him. “I was angry enough to pick up a Kalashnikov,” he says.Rolly Tambara, who were held in captivity together (Seychelles Nation)The thing that stopped him was the memory of his father’s suicide. His logic was that he didn’t want his mother to have to bear witness to both the men in her life self-destructing. His mother becomes one of the heroes of the book. German in origin, Marlis was still playing tennis and golf, and was due to have lunch at a Mexican restaurant when five men in suits (unheard of in Redondo Beach) turned up at her door. Schooled by the FBI, she had to conduct ransom negotiations herself over the phone, driving the price down from $20m&nbspto $8m, then down to $5m, and finally $1.5m. In the end she recruited a mercenary to deliver $700,000, which she&nbspmanaged to cobble together from different sources, friends, family and Der Spiegel.“I’m still angry,” Michael says, “about losing more than two years of my life.” But he had to rein in his anger if he wanted to live. When he explained he needed a doctor for his broken wrist the trigger-happy guard said to him, “You mean it was broken in this operation.” He was tempted to reply, “No motherf***er, I’m in the habit of walking around Somalia with a broken wrist.” “Yes” is how he chooses – rather carefully – to phrase it.He developed friendships with the other hostages – Chinese, Cambodian, Vietnamese, Filipinos –and he came around to liking some of the guards. But he was never tempted by Stockholm syndrome: “I went through a long period of wanting to kill them.” Notably one guy by the name of Ali.Werne)Sometimes your reading can save your life. In Moore’s case it was Epictetus, the great stoic philosopher. Stoicism says that you can’t do a lot about your fate, but you can control your attitude towards it. Epictetus asks the question, what do you do if your servant drops your favourite vase and it smashes into a thousand pieces? Do you lash out and whip the servant, or do you say – which is what he recommends – “the vase has been restored”. Moore grits his teeth and develops a sense of humour about his predicament. “Not that I laughed every day.”&nbspWhen he was staring down the barrel of a gun, quite literally, he learned to sit and accept the prospect of a sudden death. “I had to train my mind for actual non-existence.”As well as ancient Greek philosophers, a collection of Tom and Jerry cartoons definitely helps. As does news, on a short-wave radio, of the World Cup in Brazil in 2014, when Germany thrashed Brazil 7-1 in the semi-final.&nbspThere is an ironic twist in Moore’s story, when most of the people who tormented him for so long are annihilated, in a way he could never have anticipated, but which reflects what he writes about the rise of “factionalism and violent opportunism”. One further irony:&nbspwhen he gets free he even has one of his former captors becoming a Facebook “friend”.Disney removes bride auction scene on ‘Pirates of the Caribbean’ ride‘Porch pirates’ steal 4-year-old boy’s supply of life-saving medicineMaybe he could have made it as an astronaut, but he is the most persistent and unstoppable of writers. He simply stole a pen and paper from the pirates and wrote about his experiences, like a Solzhenitsyn of the Somali gulag. But these samizdats never see the light of day. When his guards read their own names they confiscate his notebooks, again and again. Finally he realises his only way out is fiction. He sets his novel in southern California, not in Somalia. About a quixotic innocent who is kidnapped by bad guys. It was partly allegory, to remind him of what happened, but now it’s in danger of becoming his next book.For Michael Scott Moore, writing is therapy, a way of retaining sanity. “To put painful events into a certain order, I had to find a way through it. The easiest thing was to set down what happened.”I asked him what he missed most during his 977 days. “I’m not sure there was any one thing. Beer? Fresh fruit? Above all my family and friends. Everything about my old life, good and bad,” he said. “I was just grateful to be alive in the end.”There is almost a note of sadness or nostalgia in his voice when he says that the traditional Somali pirate is now virtually extinct. “The business model has evolved. They’ve shifted into arms and human trafficking. Piracy has become too dangerous.”Andy Martin is the author of ‘Reacher Said Nothing: Lee Child and the Making of Make Me’, and&nbspteaches at the University of Cambridge‘The Desert and the Sea:&nbsp977 Days Captive on the Somali Pirate Coast’, by Michael Scott Moore, is published by Harper CollinsShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no Independent Minds comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsEnter your email to follow new comments on this article.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Want to discuss real-world problems, be involved in the most engaging discussions and hear from the journalists? employee representatives, the 20192020 pay negotiations in our UK plant and technical centre will commence in 2019 when we have better clarity on the future business outlook,” a spokesperson said.The UK car industry is particularly vulnerable to potential trade barriers after Brexit because firms rely on hundreds of parts crossing from mainland Europe, meaning delays caused by additional checks or paperwork could be costly.Raab: Those fearing Brexit hit to car industry should show ‘mettle’Landmark EU-Japan deal puts pressure on UK over car manufacturing jobsTrump tariffs could cost Alabama car hard Brexit would have “serious implications” for its Sunderland factory.&nbspThe company employs around 8,000 people in the UK, and announced in April it would&nbspshed hundreds of staff because of plummeting demand for diesel cars.Sales of diesels are down almost 40 per cent in 12 months, thanks to confusion about their environmental impact.Nissan said in 2016, it would build two new models at And it is all part of the company's plan to finally turn the huge amount of hype around its phones into a similarly huge number of sales.But the new carrier announcements are also actually an extension of the work the company has already done in building its brand and encouraging people to recommend its phones, the company says. And it is adamant it will not come at the cost of the things that have made the phones so beloved, such as the engagement with its community that decides everything including what the phones look like and what features are added to them.OnePlus 6T: Release date announced for super-charged AndroidWe’re a digital brand first, and that means word of mouth is very important – it’s the number one way new users hear about us, Carl Pei, co-founder and head of brand of OnePlus, tells The Independent&nbspin an exclusive interview. You may think that this is counter-intuitive, but partners like EE and Vodafone are actually an extension of our online strategy.Our users advocate us to their friends and family, and having high-street visibility means that now people can try our device in-store. The brand endorsement and support that these prestigious carriers and retailers have given us can also be taken as a compliment.Pei&nbspsays that the new shot at the mainstream won't change the way the products are designed and made. It will only expand the number of people who are able to contribute towards new ideas and feed back on old ones, he says, allowing OnePlus to keep that approach even while it expands the number of people who are a part of it.As we grow, we’ll get more feedback and pressure about our design choices –&nbspwe only add features which can improve the experience, not because they’re in fashion, he says.&nbspIt’s important to understand what people really need.The UK OnePlus forum&nbspis already one of the most engaged of any country in the world, with 1.5 million active users. More than 1,000 Britons turned up to see the reveal of the&nbspOnePlus&nbsp6, its latest phone, and it would go on to sell more than a million of those devices.OnePlus 5 smartphone at a OnePlus pop-up store at the Bikini Berlin shopping mall on June 21, 2017 in Berlin, Germany (Sean GallupGetty Images)OnePlus has inspired fanatical devotion in its customers, who queue up for the phones and flock to the launch events. Some of that devotion was inspired precisely because the phones have been so complicated to buy: at the beginning, they could only be got through an invitation system that meant users felt they had been allowed access to club, and that exclusivity encouraged loyalty.But Pei&nbspis clear that OnePlus doesn't intend to give up on that customer – or fan –&nbsprelationship, even if there are many more customers that are a part of it.We’ve always been very focused on our users and we’ll have to work hard to ensure current users feel valued, and new users are welcomed. It’s easy for brands to forget where they’ve come from – we’ve learned a lot from others in the industry, both in success and failure, he says.We’re committed to keeping our core and staying grounded, while expanding our business. The ultimate driver of people wanting to support you is having a great product, and that’s followed by having great service. The product attracts you at first, but it’s long-term service which will keep you loyal. title: spotify netflix blocked brexit no deal watch eu blocked uk british holiday latest
story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsEU regulations currently ensure people can get to their home libraries even when abroadClick to followThe Independent TechSpotify&nbspmusic, Netflix&nbspshows and content on other online streaming services could be blocked to British citizens on holiday in Europe if the UK leaves the EU with no deal, the government has admitted.At the moment, ‘portability’&nbspregulation ensures that streaming services are not allowed to discriminate between someone when they are at home in the UK or if they are travelling to the rest of Europe. Users can go on holiday to France and still have full access to the&nbspNetflix films and Spotify&nbspmusic they get at home, for instance.But a tranche of newly-released official&nbspdocuments about the anticipated impact of a no-deal Brexit includes a paper that suggests the portability&nbsparrangement that exists with the bloc would “cease to apply”.Created with Sketch. Show all 9Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Brexit Resignation: July 10th 2018 Maria Caulfield MP Conservative Party's vice chair for women July 10th 2018Brexit Resignation: July 9th 2018 Conservative MP for Bolton West Chris Green MPBrexit Resignation: July 9th 2018 Conor Burns MP next to Boris JohnsonBrexit Resignation: July 9th 2018 Steve Baker, EX-Minister at the Department for Exiting the European UnionBrexit Resignation: July 8th 2018 MP David Davis Ex-Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union Brexit Resignation: July 10th 2018 Maria Caulfield MP Conservative Party's vice chair for women July 10th 2018Brexit Resignation: July 9th 2018 Conservative MP for Bolton West Chris Green MPBrexit Resignation: July 9th 2018 Conor Burns MP next to Boris JohnsonBrexit Resignation: July 9th 2018 Steve Baker, EX-Minister at the Department for Exiting the European UnionBrexit Resignation: July 8th 2018 MP David Davis Ex-Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union “This means online content service providers will not be required or able to offer cross-border access to UK consumers under the EU Regulation,” the papers make clear. “UK consumers may see restrictions to their online content services when they temporarily visit the EU.”The rules were agreed in 2017 and have been in force since April.Netflix made clear that its customers would still be able to access the service in the event of a no-deal Brexit. But when they do so they will most likely see the library of the country they are in, as happens if Britons travel outside of the European Union now.“UK Netflix subscribers are able to access Netflix everywhere in the world Netflix is available and will continue to do so once the UK leaves the EU,” a Netflix spokesperson said. The company said that “local catalogues vary due to licensing and local tastes”, but pointed out its original shows are available everywhere.The new papers also make clear that the same regulations would apply to geo-blocking regulation. That ensures that people can buy from online services across the continent, without being punished for doing so from another country.“Following repeal of the Geo-Blocking Regulation in the UK, traders from the UK, EU and third countries would not be prohibited from discriminating between EU customers and UK customers,” the papers say.“For instance a UK trader would be able to offer different terms to a UK customer compared to a French customer.”Companies based in the UK and selling products and services in the EU&nbspwill still have to comply with the regulation, to ensure that they don’t discriminate between people in different countries within Europe.The new geo-blocking rules go into effect in December 2018, meaning that they will apply to UK citizens for about&nbspthree months before a possible no-deal Brexit in March 2019.The paper covering ‘Geo-blocking of online content if there’s no Brexit deal’ and another covering portability of content&nbspis one of a range of papers released in the latest set of documents from the UK government. They also include new documents showing Britain could no longer benefit from deals that represent a significant portion of UK trade and that train journeys into and out of the EU could be disrupted.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no Independent Minds comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsEnter your email to follow new comments on this article.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Want to discuss real-world problems, be involved in the most engaging discussions and hear from the journalists? story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsAre we tumbling towards a no deal? Europe correspondent Jon Stone explores&nbspthe latest dip on&nbspthe&nbspBrussels&nbsproller coasterClick to followIndy PoliticsWith the European Council summit looming, the Irish border is still a sticking pointWhat just happened? All weekend, news trickling out of Brexit talks became more and more positive. By Sunday lunchtime EU diplomats were certain a deal had been agreed. Dominic Raab, the Brexit secretary, headed out to Brussels to confirm it all – or so we thought.Then the Brexit roller coaster hit yet another big dipper: after a shorter-than expected meeting between Raab and Michel Barnier, it was all off again, and we were, in the words of one official “back to square one”.Anyone following these talks will have become accustomed to twists and turns, but with this week’s European Council summit looming – the “moment of truth” –&nbsp the stakes are higher than ever. The Irish border, and the so-called “backstop” is the sticking point.A deal of sorts appears to have been agreed: The Independent understands that an agreement at a technical level – between officials – was struck. But agreement at a political level is a different question entirely.&nbspTalks are shrouded in secrecy, and leaks from them are prone to spin. But as far as we can tell EU appears to have agreed to the UK plan that would, with some caveats, keep the whole UK inside the customs union to prevent any borders around Northern Ireland – either between it and Great Britain, or it and Northern Ireland.This had been proposed by the UK to placate the DUP – who want no difference in treatment between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK, and who say they would sink any deal that did. Most people believe they’re single-minded enough to carry through on their threat.But sources say Brussels is sceptical that this plan would work – and so are insisting on what has been dubbed “the backstop to the backstop”. The thinking here goes that if the UK’s political instability means that if trade talks collapse and the UK has second thoughts about being tied to the EU customs union, the original EU plan to prevent a hard border between Ireland and Northern Ireland would step up.The prime minister is probably cursing herself for calling last year’s electionBut this was unacceptable to the British government, who don’t think they could get even this past the DUP.There is a fundamental tension for the UK government which restricts their freedom to compromise in talks: lean towards a customs union for the whole UK to placate the DUP, and Tory Eurosceptics get angry because they want to be outside the customs union. But lean too hard the other way, and make the backstop more specific to Northern Ireland, and the DUP withdraw their votes.With a razor-thin majority in the Commons the government can’t really afford to lose either. Ultimately it is now parliament, and what the government can get through, that is the biggest obstacle to signing a deal.&nbspSo what happens next? There are no more talks between officials until the European Council summit later this week, where leaders will discuss their response. The negotiations teams – who both speak very highly of each other – clearly believe they have gone as far as they can within the instructions they have been given by their respectively political leaderships.&nbspCreated with Sketch.Brexit threatens life on the Irish border: in pictures Show all 15Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.John Murphy flies the European flag outside his home near the border village of Forkhill, Co ArmaghAn abandoned shop is seen in Mullan, Co Monaghan. We could cross it six or eight times a day,’ said Crockett. ‘If there was any sort of obstruction it would slow down our work every day’A defaced ‘Welcome to Northern Ireland’ sign stands on the border in Middletown, Co ArmaghPotter Brenda McGinn stands outside her Mullan, Co Monaghan, studio – the former Jas Boylan shoe factory which was the main employer in the area until it shut down due to the Troubles. ‘When I came back, this would have been somewhere you would have driven through and have been quite sad. It was a decrepit looking village,’ said McGinn, whose Busy Bee Ceramics is one of a handful of enterprises restoring life to the community. ‘Now this is a revitalised, old hidden village’Union Flag colours painted on kerbstones and bus-stops along the border village of Newbuildings, Co DerryLondonderryGrass reflected in Lattone Lough, which is split by the border between Cavan and Fermanagh, seen from near Ballinacor, Northern IrelandDonegalman David McClintock sits in the Border Cafe in the village of Muff, which straddles Donegal and DerryLondonderryAn old Irish phone box stands alongside a bus stop in the border town of Glaslough, Co MonaghanBillboards are viewed from inside a disused customs hut in Carrickcarnon, Co Down, on the border with Co Louth in the RepublicSeamus McQuaid takes packages that locals on the Irish side of the border have delivered to his business, McQuaid Auto-Parts, to save money on postal fees, near the Co Fermanagh village of Newtownbutler. ‘I live in the south but the business is in the North,’ said McQaid. Some speculate that Theresa May could simply wait: let the threat of a no deal loom ever larger and increase pressure on MPs to back the technical accord. Others fear that this is wishful thinking and that a no deal may now be more likely than not. &nbspEither way, with the composition of the House of Commons the main obstacle to a deal, the prime minister is probably cursing herself for calling last year’s election, blowing her majority, and putting the DUP in the driving seat.The Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are given a voice on the final Brexit deal.Sign our petition hereShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - Bullying and harassment have no place in the House of Commons&nbspand the Parliamentary Digital Service.&nbspWe fully accept the need for change and, as a leadership team, are determined to learn lessons from the report. We apologise for past failings and are committed to changing our culture for the better.&nbspAs Dame Laura recognises, this will not be achieved overnight. We have already begun the process.&nbspThere was an additional meeting of the Commons Executive Board earlier today and the House of Commons Commission will meet on Monday 22 October specifically to consider the report’s findings and identify next steps.&nbsp&nbspWe are grateful to Dame Laura and to everyone who contributed to the Inquiry. This report will help ensure that positive change takes place.Valerie Vaz, shadow Commons leader, said some of the accounts in Dame Laura Cox report were truly shocking.&nbspShe said: “Sexual harassment and bullying must not be tolerated in any workplace. Some of the accounts in this report are truly shocking.&nbsp“The House of Commons has recently passed an independent complaints process to deal with cases of bullying, sexual harassment and victimisation under the supervision of the Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards.&nbspShe added: We will continue to work on a cross-party basis to tackle this and ensure new procedures are as robust and effective as possible in order to protect everyone working in and visiting the House of Commons.”An interesting development in the Commons - the government has pulled key business linked to a crackdown on knife and acid sales.Theresa May will speak to French president Emmanuel Macron on Monday evening ahead of the European Council meeting, Downing Street has confirmed.Mr Macron told a press conference in Paris that he would discuss Brexit with the Prime Minister ahead of Wednesday's two-day summit.Her official spokesman confirmed they were to speak by telephone, and said she had also recently spoken with German chancellor Angela Merkel and Dutch premier Mark Rutte.He added: She has had, as she does ahead of any European Council summit, conversations with some European leaders in recent days and she will be having more in the days to come.Quite significant. The Tory MP, Dominic Grieve, has said he will only support the government in a vote if the option for a second referendum was included - considering how opposed the PM is to such a vote, we should now put Grieve in the certain-to-vote against box on the final deal.Jeremy Corbyn is guilty of a shameless U-turn and a betrayal of the British people who voted Leave, former foreign secretary Boris Johnson has told the Commons.Referencing the Labour leader's call for the UK to stay in the customs union, Mr Johnson asked the Prime Minister to confirm the UK would take back control in December 2021.Theresa May confirmed that was her expectation, adding one of the issues still under discussion was how we can ensure we do reflect the temporary nature of the backstop, which she went on to add should not be necessary.Tory MP Anna Soubry says what we now see is complete chaos, and asks the PM to take Brexit back to the people to vote on in a fresh referendum.&nbspMay says that Parliament gave people the decision to decide its future, and it's important for the faith in democracy, that the result is respected. The People's Vote happened in 2016, and it will be respected, the PM adds.Theresa May - responding to Corbyn - says we never hear from the Labour Party exactly what deal they want.&nbsp&nbsp&nbspCorbyn says Britain deserves better than the blindfold Brexit the government is pursuing. Labour has set out our six tests, he adds.&nbspWe want a deal that allows us to strengthen rights and standards... Labour will not give the government a blank cheque.&nbsp&nbsp&nbspJeremy Corbyn responds by saying: This really is beginning to feel like Groundhog day - less than 6 months to go, and what have we got to show for it?&nbspThe Chequers plan appears to be dead in the water - even her own conference speech couldn't mention it, he adds.&nbsp&nbspAs we reach a critical point in this nation's history - we need a PM that will for once make the right decision and put the country before her party ... for too long this country has been held hostage to those in her party who want to lower rights and standards...&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbspThe PM says she wants to look the British people in the eye and tell them the backstop is only a temporary solution. She says it must be the case the backstop must not need to come into force, it should be temporary, and we must be able to make sure we cannot be kept in the backstop indefinitely.&nbsp&nbspMay says that she continues to believe a negotiated deal is the best outcome for the UK and that it is in reach.Please allow a moment for our liveblog to loadThe Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are given a voice on the final Brexit deal.Sign our petition hereShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the options'For MPs to support a bad or blindfold Brexit ... would in my view be a real dereliction of duty'Click to followIndy PoliticsTheresa May must change her Brexit approach&nbspto include&nbspcontinued membership of the single market and the customs union&nbsprather than “railroading” MPs&nbspinto a bad deal, Nicola Sturgeon has said.As&nbspBrexit talks hit an impasse ahead of a crucial EU summit, Scotland’s&nbspfirst minister urged MPs to reject any “cobbled-together agreement” and called for a Norway-style deal with Brussels, as the only “democratic compromise” that would unite different factions.Ms Sturgeon said the SNP would vote against a deal based on the prime minister’s Chequers proposals, which she described as “impractical, undesirable and undeliverable”, and she&nbspinsisted the Canada-style approach favoured by Brexiteers also lacked widespread support.Sturgeon says SNP will back new Brexit referendumShe urged MPs to reject the “false choice” between whatever deal Ms May secures and a no-deal Brexit, and not to allow themselves to be railroaded into backing the prime minister over fears of a catastrophic&nbspcliff-edge exit from the EU.The Scottish leader’s intervention comes as the prime minister was due to make an unscheduled commons statement on the state of Brexit negotiations&nbspafter weekend talks broke down over arrangements for the Irish border.SNP&nbspleader Ms Sturgeon, speaking at the Royal Society of Arts (RSA) in London, said: “In&nbspthese circumstances, it is probably the case that the only option with any chance of commanding a parliamentary majority is single market and customs union membership.“Now, I am not saying that the way to such a solution would be easy. But it might well be the only option which is not completely impossible at this stage.“It should be acceptable to the EU. It avoids the worst economic damage that Brexit will wreak. It resolves the Irish border issue. And it comes closest to reconciling the different views of Leavers and Remainers.”Brexit talks: What on earth just happened?May to make Brexit statement after Brussels talks hit impasse- liveShe accused the government of “threatening us with fire, to make us choose the frying pan”, and argued any deal Ms May presents will probably be vague about the future relationship with the EU and damaging to the UK’s interests.“For MPs to support a bad or blindfold Brexit – a cobbled together withdrawal agreement and a vague statement about our future relationship – would in my view be a real dereliction of duty,” Ms Sturgeon said.She added: “As the crucial vote looms closer, it is also time for inidual members of the House of Commons to consider what compromises they see as justified – and which are not – if they are to serve their constituents and the wider public interest.“If they do that, I believe that a common sense outcome could yet be found.”The first minister reiterated her support for a new Brexit referendum if a sensible plan cannot be agreed, an option The Independent is backing through its Final Say campaign.Scotland voted by 62 to 38 per cent&nbspin favour of remaining in the EU in 2016, and the SNP government has been vocal in its opposition to the prime minister’s exit strategy.The SNP has also argued Brexit strengthens the case for Scottish independence, heaping pressure on Conservatives north of the border.Ruth Davidson, the Scots Tory leader, hinted she would&nbspresign if&nbspNorthern Ireland&nbspwas given special trading terms with the EU in a Brexit deal, against a background of the SNP arguing&nbspfor Scotland to remain in the single market even if the rest of the UK leaves.Ms Davidson said&nbspshe “could not support” such an agreement, in a joint letter to the prime minister&nbspalso signed by&nbspDavid Mundell, the Scottish secretary.Scottish Conservative constitution spokesman Adam Tomkins said Ms Sturgeon’s speech was merely “drumming up the prospects for Scottish independence”.Created with Sketch.UK news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Prime Minister Theresa May story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsCreated with Sketch.Analysis: Pandering to populism won't always work for conservatives, argues Europe correspondent Jon StoneClick to followThe IndependentLeaders of the German Green party (Die Gruenen), Henrike Hahn, Robert Habeck and Anton Hofreiter react after to the first exit polls in the Bavarian state elections in MunichFor some time now, the narrative of German politics has been the rise of the far-right AfD: from nowhere to a minor but significant party. While the AfD haven’t gone away, Sunday’s Bavarian elections show that the story is more complicated.The main way conservatives across Europe have reacted to the rise of right-wing populism has been to steal its clothes. If this is what voters want, then they can have it, the centre right has said. And they can get it from us.Britain is the best successful example of this strategy, where Theresa May’s Tories have eaten Ukip by embracing Brexit, lambasting “citizens of nowhere” and swelling their poll share to one they have not enjoyed for decades.Brexit talks: What on earth just happened?But Bavaria is now the best example of where this approach has gone wrong. For months before the election the CSU, the regional conservative allies of Angela Merkel who have dominated politics in the state since 1949, banged on about immigration. They faced down the chancellor and forced changes in refugee policy at a national level. The goal was to show voters there was no need to vote AfD if they wanted to be mean to foreigners.When polling day came on Sunday, the CSU lost a good chunk of voters to the AfD, as expected. But it lost more, according to a polling analysis by Der Spiegel, to the Greens – swathes of its one-time supporters apparently horrified at the party’s increasingly xenophobic tenor.The Greens have been unambiguously pro-refugee and are on the rise across Germany, especially so in Bavaria. They took second place and denied the CSU a majority for only the second time since 1949 – in elections fought under a proportional system.The environmentalists, who are less radical than their UK-based counterparts but nonetheless left of centre, are now flying high in the national polls, with an increasing number of surveys showing them taking second place.They have done this before, a few years ago, when a row over nuclear power was making headlines in Germany. Merkel neutered them simply by adopting their policies and pledging to close down nuclear plants. The pragmatic chancellor may have less room for manoeuvre this time, however – with pressures both to her left and right on immigration.AfD says Islam is not welcomeThere are other strands to the story, too. The social democrats, who are in coalition with Merkel’s conservatives at a federal level, lost voters to basically everyone, sinking for fourth place. Once a force to be reckoned with, they are now in serious need of a rethink and recovery if they are to even survive. They yet show little sign of having the energy to reinvent themselves.Their story is common across Europe, from France to the Netherlands from Greece to Italy where once-powerful centre-left social democratic parties are being eviscerated. Germany’s SPD has taken a particular beating from having twice now signed up to work with the conservatives, with little to show for it. When the government does things wrong they get blamed, when it does things right, they get little credit.Whether the Greens will stay on the up is not certain. German politics for the last decade has been a bit of a carousel, with minor parties getting some time in the sun between general elections as voters search around for an alternative before losing interest. The Greens, the Left, even the Pirate Party, have all at various points had temporary surges – but the only force that has sustained increased support so far has been the far right.But what does look certain is that Germany’s conservative establishment is not immune from the rot that has been afflicting its social democratic one. story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsMounir el Motassadeq, of terrorist network the 'Hamburg cell', to be returned to Morocco following his 2006 conviction&nbspfor part in deadly&nbspplotClick to followThe IndependentGermany has deported a Moroccan man who acted as a book-keeper&nbspfor&nbspthe 911 terrorists, 17 years after the deadly attacks.Mounir el Motassadeq, a member of a terrorist organisation known as the called Hamburg cell, was imprisoned in 2006 after he was convicted of aiding lead hijacker Mohamed Atta and two other al-Qaeda extremists by paying their tuition and rent to keep the pretence that they were students.Almost 3,000 people were killed when two hijacked planes were flown into the twin towers of New York's World Trade Centre on 11 September 2001. Two more jets were taken over by terrorists, one crashing into the Pentagon and the other into a field in Pennsylvania.&nbspTrump acts as consoler-in-chief on 17th anniversary of 911 attacks911: The man who walked a high-wire between the Twin Towers reflectsRemains of a 911 victim identified with advanced DNA testingEl Motassadeq, who had protested his innocence during the 2006 trial, is now expected to be put on a flight to Marrakesh, Morocco, after being collected from his Hamburg jail cell, where he had served almost 15 years.The 44-year-old was flown by helicopter to the airport on Monday, and then escorted by two heavily armed police officers into a waiting area pending the afternoon flight, news agency dpa International reported.Frank&nbspReschreiter, the Hamburg Interior Ministry spokesman,&nbspsaid el Motassadeq would leave the country soon&nbspbut would not specify exactly when he would be returned to Morocco&nbspover fears it could jeopardise the transfer.All the necessary procedural steps for this have been ticked off according to plan, Mr Reschreiter said.El Motassadeq, who was raised in a middle-class family, came to Germany in 1993 to study engineering. It was here that he met Atta.He became a suspect after German police realised he held power of attorney over a bank account belonging to&nbspMarwan al-Shehhi, the terrorist who flew United Airlines Flight 175, a Boeing 767-200, into the south tower of the World Trade Center.El Motassadeq&nbspreceived credit for time served after his November 2001 arrest. A previous request for early release had been rejected by German courts on the basis that the al-Qaeda man was too dangerous to return to society.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no Independent Minds comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsEnter your email to follow new comments on this article.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Want to discuss real-world problems, be involved in the most engaging discussions and hear from the journalists? title: jamal khashoggi latest saudi arabia turkey sabah newspaper istanbul erdogan
story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsThe daily newspaper Sabah&nbsppurports to publish the names, photos and travel movements of 15 Saudi nationals it says arrived in Istanbul just hours before the Washington Post journalist disappearedClick to followThe IndependentA Turkish newspaper has published the names, faces, and travel movements of what it describes as the 15 Saudis allegedly involved in the disappearance of a prominent journalist who vanished in Istanbul last week. Then, online sleuths reportedly managed to use open-source material to identify at least eight of those allegedly involved in the disappearance of Jamal Khashoggi, a 59-year-old Saudi journalist, as members of Saudi security forces. One photo purported to show a member of the 15-member team hobnobbing with Mohammed bin Salman, the powerful 33-year-old Saudi crown prince who has become the primary target of&nbspMr Khashoggi’s criticisms. Another identified an alleged team member as Salah Mohammed al-Tubaigy, a name and face matching the head of forensic evidence at Saudi’s General Security department.Sabah purports to identify the 15-member Saudi team allegedly involved in the disappearance of journalist Jamal KhashoggiThe details&nbspwere published by Sabah, a mass-circulation daily newspaper close to the government of president Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Friends, family, and officials say Mr Khashoggi was lured to the Saudi consulate in Istanbul on 2 October before disappearing.&nbspTurkish media reported that security camera footage from inside the consulate was removed and that staff were ordered to go home the afternoon Mr Khashoggi arrived.On the same day, two private jets, owned by Riyadh based Sky Prime Aviation,&nbspreportedly arrived from Saudi Arabia to Istanbul’s Ataturk airport, carrying the 15 personnel, landing just hours before Mr Khashoggi’s scheduled appointment at the consulate. Some of the 15 checked in to the five-star&nbspMovenpick&nbsphotel near the Saudi consulate in Istanbul’s Levent district.&nbspBoth private jets and the 15 men departed hours later, according to Turkish officials and local press. Khashoggi: Emergence of Saudi dissident and his potentially tragic endTurkish authorities investigating the disappearance of Mr Khashoggi, a prominent Saudi with Turkish ethnic roots, have been leaking information about the probe to local and international media with what appears to be the tacit approval of government officials.Police in Istanbul have formed a special team to investigate Mr Khashoggi’s disappearance, the newspaper Milliyet reported, tasked specifically to use chemicals, dogs, and infrared light to look for DNA, blood and other traces of the journalist at the Saudi consulate in Istanbul.The Post and other media also circulated a photo, likely taken from security camera footage, showing a black Mercedes Vito van that was parked outside the consulate and left shortly after Mr Khashoggi’s arrival, parked in front of the residence of Saudi consul general Mohammad al-Otaibi.The 15-member team identified by Sabah are all Saudi men aged between 30 and 57 years old. Those purportedly tracked down via open source internet tools by Oslo-based researcher Iyad al-Baghdadi and others include: a Saudi special forces member a lieutenant colonel in the Saudi civil defence force a major and lieutenant in the Saudi air force a lieutenant in the service guarding the crown prince’s palace and an intelligence service colonel who had once been attached to the Saudi embassy in the UK.Kalin on the disappearance of a Saudi journalist Jamal KhashoggiMr Khashoggi served for years as the right-hand man of Saudi prince Turki bin Faisal, a former intelligence chief as well as Riyadh’s envoy to the US and UK.&nbspIncreasingly frustrated with Saudi Arabia’s&nbspcourse, he began to bristle at the restrictions placed on media and civil society, eventually moving to the US last year amid fears for his own safety. In recent months he had grown increasingly critical of the crown prince, who has been criticised as authoritarian despite attempts to cast himself as a reformer. Saudi officials have denied that they had anything to do with Mr Khashoggi’s disappearance, insisting he left the consulate, but without providing proof, as demanded by Mr Erdogan.&nbspThe disappearance of Mr Khashoggi, a permanent US resident, has put Washington in a tough spot. The crown prince has forged a strong alliance with the administration&nbspof Donald Trump and a personal bond with the US president’s son-in-law, Jared Kushner. US lawmakers have made tough statements about the Khashoggi affair, but the White House and State Department have been tepid. Saudi Arabia has vowed to buy $110bn in American weapons.“We’re not going to make any judgments about what had happened to him,” Heather Nauert, State Department spokeswoman, told reporters on Tuesday. “The United States is certainly concerned about his whereabouts. Senior officials at the State Department have spoken with Saudi officials through diplomatic channels about the matter. We call on the government of Saudi Arabia to conduct a thorough and transparent investigation.” Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no Independent Minds comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsEnter your email to follow new comments on this article.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?Anyone can post in open comments. title: brexit latest news labour mps theresa may brexit deal
story: Negotiations have again ground to a halt and Mrs May is preparing to address the House of Commons with a hastily-arranged statement this afternoon.Former minister Caroline Flint, along with Gareth Snell and Ruth Smeeth, have all ruled out voting against the agreement Mrs May thrashed out in Brussels if the only alternative is a no-deal Brexit.Their votes could be the difference between the Prime Minister getting her plans through the House of Commons and her dealing failing altogether.Labour has declared it will only support the final Brexit deal on the so-call meaningful vote in Parliament if the plan passes Sir Keir Starmer&rsquos six tests.                Brexit news: Half of cabinet in threat to quit over BrexitBut critics within Jeremy Corbyn&rsquos party say the conditions are too restrictive and were designed to ensure Mrs May could never satisfy them.Caroline Flint, a former Government minister, said she would vote for a reasonable deal because leaving without an agreement doesn't serve the country's interests of Labour's interests.She said: I believe if there is a reasonable deal that stops us crashing out with no deal, we shouldn&rsquot rule it out.The problem is, we are now - those of us who want to get a deal - are sometimes stuck between a rock and a hard place between hardline Brexiteers who think we can waltz off without a deal and some hardline Remainers who, for their own reasons, don't want a deal because they want to overturn the referendum results.Caroline Flint would support Theresa May to avoid a no-deal Brexit (Image: )Theresa May is facing turmoil within her own party (Image: )Stoke-on-Trent Central MP Gareth Snell and Stoke-on-Trent North MP Ruth Smeeth also indicated they could support the Prime Minister.Around 15 Labour MPs are thought to have decided to back Mrs May while some estimate as many as 30 could do the same.But it is understood that Conservative whips and senior politicians have yet to extend a formal offer or ask for talks with Labour MPs to secure their support, indicating they are not yet relying on Labour votes to get the deal through Parliament.Downing Street has insisted the Prime Minister remains confident of getting a Brexit deal, despite the failure to bridge differences over the future of the Irish border ahead of this week's crunch summit.                Iain Duncan Smith ATTACKS 'intolerable' EU for trying to 'CARVE up UK'                Brexit news: Hunt hints deal will only be complete with 'good will'Mrs May is set to address MPs in the House of Commons on the state of Brexit negotiations on Monday afternoon after talks over the weekend failed to produce the hoped-for breakthrough on the so-called backstop arrangements for Ireland.The impasse means that meetings between sherpas in Brussels have been cancelled, and UK Government ministers will have no withdrawal plan to approve at Cabinet on Tuesday, before Mrs May travels to the European Council summit the following day.European Commission spokesman Margaritis Schinas said: Despite intensive negotiations several key issues remain unresolved. I can say that no further negotiations are planned ahead of the European Council.The PM's official spokesman said that real progress had been made on a number of issues and the Government was determined to press on with talks.Brexit talks have ground to a halt (Image: )But he said that the EU continued to insist on the possibility of a carve-out for Northern Ireland which could see a customs border down the Irish Sea - something Mrs May has already said would be unacceptable to any British Prime Minister.Britain is offering a temporary backstop arrangement under which the whole UK would remain in the EU customs area unless an open border in Ireland was secured by a broader trade agreement.

title: brexit news no deal dominic raab michel barnier theresa may dup
story: Brexit negotiations appear to have reached another stalemate after talks broke down between Brexit secretary Dominic Raab and EU negotiator Michel Barnier.After an hour of talks, Mr Raab made it clear that the UK would not sign the latest draft on an agreement that EU officials worked on.As a result, a meeting of EU officials to discuss a potential deal before a summit of European leader on Wednesday has been cancelled.DUP Brexit spokesman Sammy Wilson said that no-deal Brexit was probably &ldquoinevitable.                Ways we can help to fight the scourge of loneliness &ndash&nbspEXPRESS COMMENT                Labour MPs could secure PM&rsquos Brexit deal with EUHe said: &ldquoGiven the way in which the EU has behaved and the corner they&rsquove put Theresa May into, there&rsquos no deal which I can see at present which will command a majority in the House of Commons.&ldquoSo it is probably inevitable that we will end up with a no-deal scenario.But Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt claimed a deal was still possible as he threw his support behind the Prime Minister.He said: &ldquoI think everyone in the UK should have confidence that this prime minister, Theresa May, will never sign a deal that is not compatible with the letter and spirit of the referendum result.Sammy Wilson said that no-deal Brexit was probably &ldquoinevitable (Image: )Mr Raab made it clear that the UK would not sign the latest draft on an agreement  (Image: )&ldquoBut we also firmly believe that we can find a deal on that basis that works for the European Union and our partners and friends in Europe.Mr Raab told his counterpart that the UK would not agree to remaining in a post-Brexit customs union with the EU unless it contained an endpoint.The Brexit secretary also raised objects to the EU proposal to break the deadlock.This would allow a break clause to be inserted in the customs deal but only if Northern Ireland was excluded from it.Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt claimed a deal was still possible  (Image: )It would lead to customs checks on good travelling between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK.Mrs May said this is unacceptable as it would undermine the integrity of the UK by effectively creating a &ldquonew border in the Irish sea.The Prime Minister has called an emergency meeting of Commons as there amid rumours she faces rebellion over her Brexit stance.The Prime Minister will address the House of Commons today, just two days before a crucial summit in Brussels.

title: brexit news uk strategy brussels
story: Hendrik Kafsack, an economics journalist based in Brussels, told the German newspaper Franffurter Allgemeine he did not believe the UK would crash out of the EU without a deal.&nbspMr Kafsack said Brexit negotiations are &ldquoa game of chicken but said, despite EU scaremongering, a no-deal scenario is unlikely.&nbspMr Kafsack, said: &ldquoFrom a Brussels point of view, the negotiations were and are a &lsquogame of chicken&rsquo in which two cars rush towards each other, except that the European Union sits in a Mercedes SUV and the British in a mini.&ldquoSo there is no question that in doubt, the British will first turn the wheel around to dodge.                Second Brexit vote will &lsquoPOISON DEMOCRACY!&rsquo May must do THIS instead                Furious Brexiteer promises to ensure &lsquocivil UNREST&rsquo if Brexit overturn&ldquoThat always carries the risk of a collision, especially as it is unclear who is actually steering the London mini.Mr Hafsack added the UK has submitted to the EU&rsquos red lines and budged on negotiations, but without the bloc reciprocating.&nbspFor instance, the EU wants the UK to submit to the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice, where necessary, and Mr Hafsack argued that the UK will accept this even if an interposed arbitration court will blur the rule of the &ldquoforeign judges.&nbspHis comments follow a disastrous summit in Salzburg with EU leaders where government sources warned that the talks hit a &ldquoreal problem over the issue of the Irish border on 14 October.&nbspEconomics expert has blasted the EU Brexit strategy as 'irrational' (Image: getty)Theresa May said she would NEVER accept a hard border with Northern Ireland (Image: getty)Prime Minister Theresa May told MPs today a backstop, described as an insurance policy for the people of Northern Ireland, will exist as a temporary solution to avoid a &ldquopermanent limbo.However, Mrs May said she would never accept a hard border and that she will push to have a deal arranged in time, escaping the need to use the backstop.&nbspA fundamental change in the day-to-day experience of those living across Ireland would be caused by this, she said.Instead a UK-wide solution is to be proposed.Mr Hafsack added that Mrs May did not come up with any viable solution for Ireland until July in Chequers - almost three months after talks begun on 19 March this year.&nbspAnother thorn in the side of the EU is that it &ldquofeels too unattractive after the euro and refugee crisis adding to difficulties in reaching an agreement, he said.&nbspBut with this in mind, Mr Hafsack has discouraged the EU from continuing its hard-line approach as the damage of a final failure in negotiations would also be enormous for the EU.&nbspHe said: &ldquoIt would be tragic because it could have been avoided with more confidence and flexibility.&nbspHad they accepted Chequers, meaning that the British would be allowed to take part in the single market for goods, May would have returned home stronger from Salzburg.&nbspThat would have made the unification easier in Brussels, but especially in London.

story: Kensington Palace said in a statement: Their Royal Highnesses The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are very pleased to announce that The Duchess of Sussex is expecting a baby in the Spring of 2019.Their Royal Highnesses have appreciated all of the support they have received from people around the world since their wedding in May and are delighted to be able to share this happy news with the public.Meghan told the Queen and the rest of the Royal Family the happy news at Princess Eugenie's wedding on Friday, it was revealed.The Queen, the Duke of Edinburgh, the Prince of Wales, the Duchess of Cornwall and Duke and Duchess of Cambridge are said to be delighted for the couple.Meghan Markle baby: What will Meghan and Prince Harry call their baby?Markle Markle royal baby will NOT or staff, and will instead depend on Doria.Meghan Markle is pregnant with her first child (Image: )Meghan Markle beamed as she greeted fans in Australia (Image: MEGAKHAPGG)Kensington Palace refuses to say if Meghan's father Thomas has been told she is pregnant.When&nbspExpress&nbspcontacted Kensington Palace in regards to Thomas being told the news a spokeswoman said they were making &ldquono comment.The exciting news comes just hours after the Duke and Duchess of Sussex touched down in Sydney&nbspfor their first major international tour.The newlyweds arrived on Monday ahead of a 16-day tour, which will take them to Australia, New Zealand, Fiji and Tonga and their first official day will see them carry out a raft of engagements in Sydney.&nbspMeghan Markle smiled and waved at Australian fans  (Image: MEGAKHAPGG)Kensington Palace said there would be no change to the itinerary of Harry and Meghan's tour including to Fiji and Tonga, despite travel advice that pregnant women should consider not travelling to the countries because of the moderate Zika virus risk.The palace said the couple had sought medical advice and decided to continue with their plans.Rumours surrounding Meghan's pregnancy reached a tipping point hours before their annonucement as she was seen clutching two purple folders to her stomach.It led eagle-eyed royal fans to take to Twitter speculating she was hiding a baby bump.                Meghan Markle pregnant: When did Meghan and Prince Harry get married?                Meghan Markle pregnant: Queen congratulated Duchess and HarryMeghan Markle beams at royal well-wishers  (Image:  MEGAKHAPGG)One user wrote: Meghan is pregnant. It's so conservative.One user added: &ldquoI have a feeling that Meghan is pregnant...she&rsquos glowing and her face looks fuller to me.. can&rsquot wait for them to announce it.Another added: Who matches their outfit to their folders? If Meghan isn&rsquot pregnant I&rsquoll be surprised because that whole outfitfolder scenario looks hella planned.The baby&nbspwill be seventh-in-line to the British throne and will be the Queen's eighth great-grandchild.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex's baby will not automatically be a prince nor a princess,&nbspunless the Queen steps in to issue a Letters Patent ahead of the birth.If the new baby is a boy he will likely take one of Harry's lesser titles, such as Earl of Dumbarton or Baron Kilkeel, which he was given by the Queen on his wedding day.But if the happy couple have a daughter she will be known as Lady Mountbatten-Windsor.However, the Queen could make changes that allow for Harry and Meghan's children to be HRHs and princes and princesses.The couple would also&nbspapply for their baby&nbspto have dual UK and US citizenship.Meghan and Prince Harry got married in May (Image: REUTERS)The Duchess of Sussex is still a US citizen and is planning on becoming a British citizen.It is not known if new mum-to-be will hold dual nationality when she does become a UK citizen.A child born outside of the US and in wedlock to a US citizen parents and a non-US citizen parent can still acquire US citizenship if the the US parent (Meghan) lived in America for five years, according to the American Embassy in the UK.Sarah Ferguson broke her silence&nbspon her daughter Princess Eugenie&rsquos royal wedding with a timely tweet minutes after it was announced Meghan Markle was pregnant.Prince Harry and Meghan have said they want to have children in the past (Image: PA)The Duchess of York gave her first public message since her daughter married Jack Brooksbank on Friday in Windsor.The tweets came out just 40 minutes after Kensington Palace announced the Duke and Duchess of Sussex were expecting a baby in Spring 2019.Grant Harrold, a former butler to Charles, William and Harry, tweeted this morning:Congratulations to The Duke and Duchess of Sussex who are expecting their first child in the spring.Prime Minister Theresa May offered her congratulations to in repsonese to the royal baby news.She said: My&nbspwarmest congratulations to the Duke and Duchess of Sussex on the happy news they are expecting a baby in the spring. Wishing them all the best.The Archbishop of Canterbury posted on Twitter: Congratulations to the Duke and Duchess of Sussex on their happy news! Prayers for them in the months ahead.The Kingdom Choir, a group of gospel singers who performed Stand By Me at Harry&nbspand Meghan's wedding, posted a message saying: We'd just like to send our congratulations to the beautiful couple, the Duke and Duchess Of Sussex on their recent announcement. love, @thekingdomchoir.The wonderful news comes as&nbspMeghan once described being a mother on her bucket list&nbspand Prince Harry has previosuly said he would love to have children.Meghan and Harry are expecting their first child in the spring of 2019 (Image: PA)Today's pregnancy announcement is a long-held ambition for the pair to become parents as they've both spoken openly about wanting to start a family.In the run-up to the wedding, Meghan had hinted to wanting to start a family with her husband.While the pair were in Belfast, the bride-to-be joked as she was shown an innovative range for newborns: I'm sure at some point we'll need the whole (lot).During the couple's engangment interview, the topic of starting a family came up.The Queen is said to be 'delighted' with the news (Image: PA)Prince Harry, 34, said: You know, I think one step at a time, and hopefully we'll start a loose-fitting and long navy coat.The covered-up look is in complete contrast from sleek dresses she has been pictured wearing at a number of events recently.Royal fans flocked to Twitter and speculated that Meghan might be expecting her first child with Harry.They appeared to be having warm and friendly chat before the ceremony started.&nbspIt is unclear if Thomas Markle knows his daughter is pregnant (Image: ITV)However, now that they have announced they are expecting their first child it seems there is more to this conversation.In one moment, Princess Anne looks down at Meghan&rsquos stomach as the her coat was unbuttoned.&nbspThen in another moment the Queen&rsquos daughter makes gestures with her hands.Charlie Proctor, the editor-in-chief of Royal Central, tweeted the video and said: &ldquoI didn't want to say anything at the time because I know how annoying the rumour mill is, but Meghan's conversation with Princess Anne suddenly makes a lot more sense now.This could be the moment Meghan told Princess Anne the exciting news (Image: NA)&ldquoAnne looking at her stomach, the hand movements etc&nbsp#RoyalBaby.The Duchess sent Twitter into a frenzy on Can&rsquot wait for them to announce it.One tweet read: &ldquoMeghan Markle is definitely pregnant. My psychic intuition does not lie and that long coat is rather suspicious.Kensington Palace had remained tight-lipped on growing speculation that Meghan is pregnant until now.Last month, Coral cut the odds on Prince Harry and Meghan's first child being born next year.&nbspThe bookmaker cut the odds to even shorter odds of 1-4, from 1-3.

title: brexit news free zones free ports brexit latest uk economy boost manufacture
story: Among the many opportunities for Britain after its withdrawal from the European Union is the possibility to create FZs, according to Catherine Barnard, Professor of EU law at Cambridge University.Ms Barnard backs this scenario, arguing FZs will represent another source of wealth after the country will be freed from the control of Brussels.Free Zones are areas, typically near ports and airports, where the usual customs rules and duties of the countries they are in do not apply.This means firms operating in FZs usually don&rsquot pay taxes and don&rsquot have to follow customs rules and regulations.&nbsp                Brexit news: UK to hand billions to EU under May's customs union plotThe law professor said: &ldquoThe most widely discussed Brexit trade opportunity is the right to strike trade agreements with countries around the world.&ldquoBut there may be other opportunities as well.&ldquoOne of them is the creation of Free Zones.Ms Barnard, who is also a senior fellow at the UK in a Changing Europe, an independent research institute looking into relations between the UK and EU, saw many perks in particular the creation of Free Ports, FZs established near ports.She said: &ldquoFree Ports as a trade opportunity are attractive for several main reasons.&nbspBrexit news: The UK should leave the single market, according to an expert (Image: )&ldquoFirst, ports are already a vital economic asset in the UK so the infrastructure for Free Ports already exists.&ldquoPorts account for 96 percent of all trade volume and 75 percent of trade value.Free Ports could also &ldquoboost manufacturing, the professor continued.Pointing out the industry only accounts for 10 percent of the total Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of the country, Ms Barnard said: &ldquoFree Ports would allow the import of semi-finished products such as automotive parts from other countries into the UK Free Ports on privileged terms.&ldquoSuch products would be stored and processed in the Free Port and then re-exported as a British product, such as cars.&nbspBrexit news: Free Zones could boost the economy in areas outside London (Image: )&ldquoThe primary market for such &lsquoMade in the UK&rsquo goods could be the EU itself.Lastly, Free Ports could boost the economy &ldquowhere jobs are needed the most, whereas now wealth and occupation are gathered in the capital.Ms Barnard said: &ldquoFree Ports could thus help re-balance the disproportionate geographical distribution of economic growth.&ldquoAccording to the former senior Treasury economist Chris Walker, Free Ports could create as many as 26,000 high-value jobs across the North East.However, the perks of FZs will only open up to Britain if the UK does not remain within the single market, as explained by Rishi Sunak, Tory MP for Richmond.&nbspBrexit news: If the UK doesn't leave the single market it won't be able to create new free zones (Image: )In his report called &lsquoThe Free Ports Opportunity&rsquo, he wrote: &ldquoAs a member of the EU Single Market and Customs Union, the UK does not have control over its trade policy.&nbsp&ldquoThe UK is not able to set its own tariff and customs duties and administration.&ldquoEU regulations would make it difficult to create US-style Free Trade Zones in the UK.&ldquoThe United Nations has concluded that: &lsquoFree Trade Zones as originally conceived do not exist anymore in the EU&rsquo.&nbspBrexit news: Free Zones are areas usually located near ports and airports (Image: )Additionally, EU state members can challenge attempts to provide other countries with Free Trade Zone incentives.&ldquoThis allows any of a thousand or more special interest groups from across the continent to block the policy in Britain.The creation of Free Ports could open as many as 86,000 jobs in the UK, according to an estimation made by the MP.A different estimate made by consulting firm Mace suggested as many as up to 150,000 new high-quality jobs could be created by FZs in post-Brexit Britain.&nbsp&nbsp

story: The Irish Taoiseach insisted Brussels is willing to compromise to avoid a hard border in Ireland while Ireland's Foreign Minister demanded Theresa May honour her previous commitment to the so-called &lsquobackstop&rsquo contingency.Mr Varadkar cast doubt on the prospect of Britain striking a withdrawal agreement this month and warned a deal could still be two months away.And while he said an exit agreement was still the most likely outcome, Mr Varadkar insisted the UK has the most to lose if a deal is not reached.He said a no-deal Brexit will be really bad for Ireland, relatively bad for the European Union but quite a disaster for the United Kingdom, the Irish Independent reports. title: Cracking Landscape picture of the year
story: Glencoe's ice shards (Image: Pete Rowbottom PA)Pete Rowbottom, of Wigan, beat thousands of other entries to win the &pound10,000 prize for his emotionally strong image of icy water in front of Glencoe's Buachaille Etive Mor.A blizzard in Derbyshire's High Peak and a dramatic black and white shot of a fisherman on the rocks at Porth Nanven, Cornwall, were among category winners in the competition.An aerial view of terraced houses in Bristol and a close-up of holly leaves in Edinburgh also topped categories.                National Geographic Travel Photographer of the Year - Nature gallery                Wildlife Photographer of the Year 2018 in picturesAwards founder and landscape photographer Charlie Waite said: The numerous strong diagonal lines of the ice fractures in Pete's image echo the shape of Buachaille Etive Mor in the background and have peaks of their own.You can't take your eyes away from the relationship between the mountain and the ice it is visually very strong and has a mathematical precision.The cold of the mountain and ice together contrast well with the amber of their surroundings.This is an image where you can hear and feel the landscape, as well as see it, so it is emotionally strong and involves the viewer on multiple levels.A coastal mountain biker (Image: Josef FitzGerald-Patrick PA)Josef FitzGerald-Patrick, 17, from Cornwall, won the Young Landscape Photographer of the Year title for his picture of a mountain biker on the coast.His shots of the dramatic coast around Land's End and Porthgwarra won him two other young photographer categories.Special awards were won by shots of a storm wave, atmospheric woodlands in the morning, an ethereal image of Daymark beacon in Devon and heather blooming above Buttermere in the Lake District.A fisherman in battered Cornwall (Image: Mick Blakey PA)The Network Rail Lines in the Landscape award was won by Alan Courtney of Wimborne, Dorset, for his sunset shot of a train speeding across Holes Bay in his home county.Winning entries will be shown on The Balcony at London's Waterloo station for 12 weeks from November 19, before going on tour to other UK stations.

title: British know how fuels mission to uncover secrets of planet Mercury
story: Artist's impression of the two probes orbiting Mercury (Image: EsaPA Wire)The spacecraft will have a lightweight ion drive, dispensing with the usual chemical system which would have needed 17 tons of propellant.Instead the engines, made in Stevenage, Hertfordshire, will have just half a ton.The European Space Agency's BepiColombo is due to blast off with conventional rockets from French Guiana on Saturday.&nbsp                How to see Mercury TONIGHT: Bright planet visible in the night skies                Miracle escape at 164,000ftIt will send two orbiters around the planet to explore a world where temperatures can reach 900F (450C).It is the planet nearest to the Sun.One of the probes was made at Airbus Space and Defence, in Stevenage.Only two spacecraft have previously visited Mercury. Nasa's Mariner 10 flew past the planet three times in 1974 and 1975 and a US Messenger probe orbited from 2011 to 2015, taking photos of the surface.Dr Jerry Bolter, project manager at Airbus, said: The only other spacecraft to go in orbit was Messenger.That was a very, very light spacecraft and nowhere near as capable as Bepi.
